website_summaries.verdict: A terrific introductory scanner for those just getting into ham radio.
pros: Frequency range of 400 to 470 MHz for outstanding coverage
Includes a USB programmable cable and software
Comes with AC charger, battery, belt clip, antenna, and manual
cons: Power switch may need to be re-cycled regularly

customer_reviews.title: Loaded with custom firmware made the MD-380 even better!
customer_reviews.text: Out of the box, it's a great radio. However, it's possible to make it even better by loading a custom firmware called 'MD380Tools' which allows the entire DMR database to be loaded onto the radio (currently more than 52,000 calls). With the new firmware, the Talkgroup, station's ID, call sign, name and QTH are displayed (see screen display after mod attached).
customer_reviews.author: Ruby

customer_reviews.title: Great Radio
customer_reviews.text: The MD-380 is a superb radio. If you're a HAM looking to get on DMR you couldn't find a better radio for even a remotely decent price. Easy to program, easy to use. Audio is super clear and sounds great. I really like the channel selector and if you're careful when you organize your channels inside the zone, you can be on the same talkgroup when you switch zones. Great radio, don't hesitate.
customer_reviews.author: Eric Walton

customer_reviews.title: Not great for basic ham
customer_reviews.text: DMR.... Over complicated no programming without the computer. Also on a conventional repeater These also don't work far. I can't get into the repeater unless I step outside. I'm 10 miles from the repeater. I will stick to my baofeng uv5r. These dmr radios are not great. I don't see this as a viable option for the hobbiest only commercial applications and maybe people who have time to spend sorting through hours of frequencies and talk groups. My biggest complaint is that this radio is not able to transmit in my house. My cheap radio even works fine inside. This one just doesn't cut it.
customer_reviews.author: Dg3toyota

customer_reviews.title: DRM workhorse for the ham.
customer_reviews.text: Had the product for almost 2 years and still works very well. It's a battle tank, has hit the floor several times and still looks new. If you don't like the firmware that comes on it, just find a load from the DMR community that fits your needs and you are going to be happy. You can always re-flash to the original code if you go to the TYT page and download the latest version.

customer_reviews.title: Better Than Expected!
customer_reviews.text: I do not have my HAM license yet. So, I will do nothing with this till I am 'legally' able to use it. I do not want to anger the FCC, before I get started. I saw many people say on Youtube that they would not want to drop this unit. I totally disagree. I would bet this unit would handle being dropped way better than my BCD 436 HP $500.00 scanner. JMO Well constructed, Compact, but not cheap feeling. I realize this is entry level, but I bet I will be using this unit for years to come. And, what they say comes in the box, actually comes in the box. Includeing CD Rom.

If it had a louder speaker and could program repeaters and talkgroups from the front panel, I would have given it 5 stars.

Generally speaking it seems the current support for this new version of radio is rather lacking.

customer_reviews.title: Prone to breaking, short warranty, difficulty in getting support
customer_reviews.text: After owning two MD-380's for six months, one has begun to malfunction. The radio apparently broadcasts (as a digital signal) a warbling screech, unless an external speaker microphone is used. I re-programmed multiple MD-380's and Vertex 531's to all talk to one another using the same frequencies and color codes, and this can be reproduced across all of them; apparently the broken MD-380 is indeed encoding a warbling screech and broadcasting it (which indicates a faulty internal microphone and/or connection to me). Sadly, the warranty on these is only a mere 6 months from the manufacturer, and the seller has not responded to my inquiry. These radios are extremely fragile and prone to breaking.

Many Ham operators have purchased this entry-level radio, so there are lots of YouTube video reviews available as well as ”how to” videos covering setup and programming. There is also a lot of MD380 info available on various FaceBook DMR forums. My first MD380 was defective but Amazon took it back and immediately credited my account. The second radio works well and I’ve been using it, in conjunction with a hotspot, to talk with ham radio operators all over.

customer_reviews.title: New standard HT for non-bat DMR and first-timers

I have upgraded it with MD380-Tools and that made it even more feature-rich. Be sure to get the VHF model or the UHF model for whatever your local conditions are. This unit is expandable, with accessories such as mic / speaker / antenna / dongle but remember that this is a stand-alone HT by design and it works wonderfully well in this manner, with everything that comes in the box. In that respect, it's an unbeatable price for that performance. Also remember that it is a fully functional (analog) HT at the same time. 73!

customer_reviews.title: Awesome entry radio to DMR.
customer_reviews.text: I bought 3 of them. (2) UHF 380 (non-gps) & (1) VHF 380G (Gps model). The 380tools firmware works on all 3 units. The 380tools firmware really makes this an awesome radio to use for hamradio. I installed md380tools via the VMware method. It creates a virtual Linux/Unix environment on a windows PC. Allowing you to safely update/compile//install the latest md380tools firmware and upload the Full DMR ID/callsign database. Now up to 61,000 DMR IDs for hamradio (May/2017).
